instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2: What is SMC_PM_G2? This is a typo of SMC_PM_G2_EN When you see SMC_PM_G2, assume they meant to type SMC_PM_G2_EN.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWGD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWGD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message:
Hi,
liquid on this board near <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>, PPBUS short, i remove <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> & change it, PPBUS is now normal at 12,56V
All rail S5 is good but the rest is at 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2</SIGNAL>=3,427V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3</SIGNAL>=3,428V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWGD</SIGNAL>=0V
i don't find any another area liquid spill on the board.
can you help me please?
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message:
Probably dead CPU, because voltage spike on VCORE.

You should check power on sequence at least.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
Post <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Also check all 4 RTC signals at PCH.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for reaction (drop pulse) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

Be sure to use 85W Magsafe 2 charger...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=3,4
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>=3,21
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>=3,26
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>=3,4 
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>=3,32 without battery
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>=3,42
When i Short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> go to 0 and come back after to 3,4
i use a apple 85W m2
CPU dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=3,4
-------------------
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=0"
Check diode mode to ground there.
SMC should pull high this signal.
Try reballing SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message: reball the SMC if <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message: <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> sent 12.56 volts to the CPU and this can RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message:
"When i Short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> go to 0 and come back after to 3,4"
Check if all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals pulse at least, at same moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message:
sorry for the late reply
I check all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> all make a high rise signal to 3,4 when i short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOF</SIGNAL> and come back to 0V
What can i see?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message: Then S3/0 voltages should pulse too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led & orange, but nothing
threads.message: Yes S3 and S0 pulse, is it normal?
